comment_0: This is about some kid talking to Maynard about Undertow.  The kid, declaring himself a true Tool fan (OGT - Original Gangsta Tool) apparently called MJK a sellout for releasing Undertow, a major label record.  Maynard turns his words around into the chorus that says, "We all participate in capitalism, so by saying you don't like it, you're being hypocritical."  He goes on to say that the kid knows nothing about him except for what Maynard lets him know, so he's in no position to tell him how to live.  Just invest in Tool and your soul is safe.
comment_1: I disagree. I don't think that he's saying capitalism is the H w/ a P, He's saying that HE's the H w/ a P.  He's like "You know what buddy, (I love when he says buddy!) I might have sold myself (hooker), but I'M still the one who fucking YOU!(-he's got the cock) So fuck you."  That's what it is.  Most definitely.
comment_2:
I think you guys are wrong about the name
I think that Hooker With A Penis is a reference to "You only know what I've sold you"
Meaning, You only know the surface of Maynard. I.E. What he wants you to know.
He's the hooker and you don't know he has a penis.
Which is saying that you have no idea what really lies beneath.
comment_3: This song taught me everything I needed to know to pass High School economics
comment_4:
I don't think this song is purposefully about capitalism. It's more about hypocrisy, just Maynard responding to people who tell the band that they are selling out.

This kid has the audacity to tell Maynard that Tool is "selling out and sucking up to the man" for making a major-label record, even though he's wearing brand name clothes, drinking Coke, and getting tattoos of products. And Maynard is calling him out on his hypocrisy and telling him that unless he's willing to throw away his clothes and get rid of his tattoos, he can just shut his fucking mouth.
comment_5: All I have to say is why does this song have the rating it does? What fool rated it low? This song is not only hilarious but it brings a good point across and is just entertaining. The chorus is great to sing along with. Tool will always be a great band.
comment_6:
This song is a big FUCK to all the "dip shit" who repeatedly call bands sell outs. EVERY single band who ever releases an album is litterally a sell out. MJK is basically telling all of them "We live in a capitalist world, deal with it. Criticizing bands for this only shows you're a dumb fuck who's completely missing the point. You're criticizing, but you're the one getting fucked in the end, so don't tell me what to do." 

I think we can apply this message to other aspects of the world than the capitalist system. This represents the essence of Maynard's message saying , we all have our flaws, don't be a fuckin' hypocrite and admit that you are a inperfect person as well. The world would be a much more peaceful place if more people thaught this way.
comment_8: i like that tool throw's out props to the beastie boys. Honestly, we as fans dont truly know the individuals writing and recording these songs, and I think the point of this entire song is that whether or not TOOL sold out or not is irrelevent because the music that they write and produce continues to be amazing and what we the consumer want more and more of. Honestly, there people just like everyone else. They believe what they want and leave the rest up to the individual to believe what they want. At the end of the day, there pretty awesome and create well thought out and well put togethor music that we all love and enjoy. If that makes them a "sale out" then so be it, im going to keep buying there shit.

comment_17: Although I always thought this was about capitalism, I have to admit that Galactic Cactus' theory makes a lot of sense. In my English 1 class, we were going into depth on capitalism and I wrote an entire essay on this song and how it portrays capitalism... my teacher (an older hippie guy) asked if I could bring in the CD so he could hear the song and he dug it. Even though I'm not sure if I believe it's about capitalism anymore, I have to admit, I B.S.ed a really damn good essay.
comment_18: they might not be a political band, but capitalism does play a role in the song's meaning. everything you see is a product with a message, and tool is no different, as maynard explains. i think galactic cactus got the meaning of the song title, although coldandugly applied the same meaning to a broader range of people just like maynard (hookers w/ penises). and isn't that what capitalism is made up of?

I didn't go straight to the symbolism, myself, but to each his own.

comment_54:
Whenever  I hear this song it reminds me of all the fans of music that I have spoken to who 'discover a great new band' and once the band puts out an album that becomes popular they dispise the band as a sell out.  The band hasn't changed, just more people have been exposed to their music; and after all, isn't that their goal, to be successful?  I'm sorry that you cann't take claim anymore for a band that was never yours, but to change your mind on a band due the way others view them is pure hypocritical vanity, your the one selling yourself out.
This is exactly what I think Maynard is refering to in his lyrics.

comment_70: I think that this whole album sounds the most demonic, aside from Disgustipated, of all.  Also, when I listen to Flood I can imagine him like a Christ figure preaching to all his listeners.  Then Lateralus is so much different even though he still kinda sounds like he's preaching.  But if there's one thing that they specifically want you to understand about their music it's that you should think about what you're hearing and try to understand the message and see how it relates to you.  It's kind of like philosophy and the one thing that sticks out in my mind when I think about philosophical teachings is that they all seem to be wrong; and their music even tells you that maybe they are wrong and you shouldn't listen to them, because they are just like the ones that they are speaking against.  Really all philosophy is, is what you personally want to get from it.  You can read(or listen in the case of Tool's music) something and completely disagree, agree, or maybe feel somewhere in between.  It all depends on the reader or listener.  However, I think that Tool does have a lot of good messages in their music.

comment_77: I'd like to point out something minor that is mentioned in this song.  I feel that the beginning of the song enlightens most to the true definition of what a sell-out is.  How many of us can honestly say that before we listened to this song, that we knew what MJK's definition of a sell-out was.  We all assume that a sell-out is someone who changes his music in order to sell more records.  MJK is kind enough to show us that anyone who makes a record must sell-out in some way.  The term "sell-out" is very hackneyed, and it's convenience has caused it to lose it's meaning since people don't think about what it means anymore.  If a band changes anymore it's so easy to say, "Man, they sold out, they totally changed, they don't respect their fans, i hate them, blah blah blah."  People shouldn't care if their band that could fit in their pocket before becomes more popular/bigger/whatever.  Like the music you like, don't take things for granted, and be self-righteous like the dude MJK talks to in the song.

comment_102:
heres my take on this song...

what i believe maynard means when he says "im the man and youre the man and hes the man as well" is that:

when people usually say something about "the man" they usually mean that there is someone or something out there that is keeping them back from their aspirations. but what maynard is saying is that the only
thing that can hold you back is yourself. so therefore everyone is "the man" themselves.

when it comes to the lyrics " i sold my soul to make a record.. and you bought one" hes saying:

when a band signs a record deal they are agreeing to make a music album (their soul) for money, in essence selling their soul for money.

comment_120:
To me personally, this song makes me think about how everything is a product. He probably wrote it as a reaction to how stupid he found being called a âsell-outâ though.

In our current society, we need to get jobs in order to make money and survive. At the end of the day, this is MJKâs job. MJK makes music to put food on the table. The primary purpose of making this song, indeed every song they have released, is to make money. There may be a message, but that message is only a secondary purpose for making this song.

MJK is a sell-out. Every musician is a sell-out. The main reason to pick up their instruments or pull out their pen in the first place is so they can earn money. They care more about surviving by earning money than entertaining you. However, itâs good to know you entertain people too. Take a look at that Ãnima CD and picture this. That isnât piece of art full of deep meaning, that is a product used to make MJK money. In our society, everything is a product. That monitor in front of you. The designer of that created it for the purpose of making money. That table, that TV, that lamp, that window, your house, everything you eat. Everything is a product designed for the fundamental purpose to make the creator money. The news doesnât report stuff you need to know, it reports stuff you will be interested so you will tune in so companies will give them money for advertising space so you will know about their products so you can buy.

If you donât want to feed âthe manâ in any way and not be a sell-out. Follow these steps.
1: Give away all their processions (including their clothes) and money
2: Move into a place where our species have not inflicted their plague of âmodern societyâ on and live there. I recommend the jungle.
3: Start a new life and live one with the animals, carefree from the pressure of the system. You've probably got the best idea acutally.

Basically it's a "Shut the fuck up" to all the people who believe that they are sell-outs "I'm the man and your the man and he's the man as well", - I'm doing what's best for myself and so should you.

He is calling the fan a whinging hypocrite with a terribly misconceived idea of what selling is all about "I sold my soul to make a record" - You sell out the instant you sign the dotted line - whether it's a major label or not. "Vans 501", "Sips of Coke" - brand names showing the kid really doesn't know what he's talking about. 

I love this song it's the exact opposite to the song "Jenny from the Block" by Jennifer Lopez (hate to bring her into a Tool conversation but there you go). Whereas Tool stands up to the kid in a level-headed and down-to-earth manner, Lopez pathetically protests to her fans pleading with them to continue to regard her as "Cool".

comment_144: Well, I don't know if this is a major factor of the song... but I have noticed that the song is entirely heavy. Maybe they're using that as a sarcastic approach towards the people complaining about how Tool isn't like how they used to be, back in the Opiate days? Just a thought.
comment_145: I think this song is about a certain conflict, a duality in MJK's mind. On one hand, he's a strong defender of a musician's right not only to make music as he or she sees fit, but also to sell it and profit from it. He's said so himself in at least one interview, strongly, and the lyrics of this song certainly imply it. So he's angry with this kid for not respecting that right of the artist. On the other hand, it sounds like he is indeed angry with that part of himself and the system. The lyrics also seem to form an indictment of the music industry itself, and the hell musicians go through to reach success, and how little that translates into respect for themselves or their art. He also seems, at least in part, to despise the pressures financial gain put on art. So I think it combines his opposite opinions on a singular issue.

comment_180: gaodene, the word is hypocritical (not meaning to sound mean or condescending, you were going in the right direction, buddy). But that isthe most important thing about the song. The kid is in all these name-brand 'Generation X' bullshit stuff that's supposedly 'breaking trends' and 'setting new boundaries' Well, got news for you. Vans is still as much a name brand as Abercrombie. Getting a Beastie Boys T is scarcely different from buying some fake surf party advertisement shirt from Hollister. And then the kid has the nerve to tell Maynard that MAYNARD sold out. To say that MAYNARD was sucking up to the man (the man in this case being popular culture). Maynard really did say it best "Before you point that finger you should know that I'm the man. And if I'm the man then you're the man and he's the fuckin man as well so you can point that fuckin finger up your ass." Maynard is saying (once again 'the man' being pop culture) that he IS pop culture, HE starts the trends everyone follows. But so is the kid. And the random guy. In other words, what's popular to one person is different to the next guy. And the next guy. And the next guy. Catch the drift? This ain't about capitalism, or L. Ron Hubbard or some other off-the-wall bullshit. It's one of VERY few Tool songs that's blunt and straightfoward, wasting no time with intricate metaphors.
comment_181: "Before you point that finger you should know that I'm the man. And if I'm the man then you're the man and he's the fuckin man as well so you can point that fuckin finger up your ass." I don't think Maynard thinks he's a trend-setter or even if he did, I don't think he'd pick this song to try and tell us that in.. I think it's more a rant against people that jump on the wave as "fans" as soon as bands become popular. And how they feel "important" by judging/critisizing the band when they really have no clue. Like stated earlier this song isn't that deep, it's more straightforward and hence this line is just a cool way for Maynard to say that: We play kickass music (I'm the man) and everyone is free to listen to it, and whoever listens openhearted without trying to judge the music or the band is "the man" aswell.

comment_185: The brilliance of Maynard lies in that the song IS about capitalism, but it's not like he's going to sing a lecture about capitalism. Saying that Tool is not a political band is simply not true. They may not have songs directly addressing political issues like APC does, but many of MJK's songs are about society and the state of man (Vicarious, The Pot, Right in Two, Aenema). His metaphors are often so deep that it's difficult to extract all of the meaning. Basically, I think Maynard sometimes intentionally writes songs with multiple multiple meanings just to spark conversation like this.

comment_205:
I love the reference to the kid sipping "coke" when talking about sellouts. And how he has NEW tattoos, claiming he was OGT. I believe Maynard was a little bit pissed off at the whole "sellout" name calling thing. And he decided to let his feelings out in song. Also, you either have to not really give a shit at all about pissing off a huge genre of fans that have purchased your "stuff." Or be so extremely confident in your music that it doesn't matter. Which I think is true in both situations with Tool. I like the last portion of the song's lyrics:

-All you read and
-Wear or see and
-Hear on TV
-Is a product
-Begging for your
-Fatass dirty
-Dollar

-So...Shut up and

-Buy my new record
-Send more money
-Fuck you, buddy

Does it getting any more clear than that?
comment_206: Wow. Phenomenal song. Tool are a simply mind-blowing entity that the world is lucky to have. Anywho, so many people I know (not on here, but in reality) immediately dismiss this song for being "fucking stupid" or only laugh at the profanities. But the fact of the matter is, this song is the work of Maynard James Keenan's lyrical genius. It is obviously about an encounter he had with a boy who claimed to be a "true" Tool fan, dressed in a fittingly ironic inauthenticity, who accused Maynard of "selling out". There are awesome meanings in the profane lines, for instance, the chorus; "I'm the man, and you're the man, and he's the man as well, so you can point that fucking finger up your ass". It shows how each and every one of us is a cog in the capitalist system, and as a result of that, every single one of us is the famed "man" who is always out to get us. And the "point that fucking finger up your ass" is obviously a blatant fuck-off that basically screams "I win, you lose. Bitch." Also, a thought on the title; a possibility as to why the song is titled "Hooker With A Penis" could be that the piercings, tattoos and other nuances of the boy's appearance made him look so ridiculous, that he almost looked feminine, or like a hooker with a penis. Just my interpretation and some food for thought.
comment_208: here is how I interrupt this part of the song,  " I sold out long before you new my name "  I think he is referring to his time in the Army here, I can relate being a service member myself as well as a poet, It really does go against the grain of who you are as an artist being in a controlled environment, Lucky for us he didn't decide to make a career out of it.  I am going Pusicfer in Vegas on the 13 of Feb. floor tickets too, My friend can't make so I  gotta an extra ticket, wanna go email me here, No BS.  this is my way of giving back to Maynard what he has given all of us.
comment_209: I think the title is a play on words. Take the lyric "...if I'm The Man then you're The Man and he's The Man as well...," and extend it to say even hookers are The Man, the play on words being that if a hooker were truly a 'man', she'd be a hooker with a penis.

comment_213:

The obvious meaning is that Maynard hates sell outs and people who think they are non-conformist while actaully conform and just fake people in general. He wants people to think for themselves, but they just listen to him w/o questioning him, which he doesn't like. I am putting words in his mouth though, thats just my interpretation of the song.
Oh and it would be hilarious if some commented like "hey, i met maynard wearing Vans, 501s, and a

comment_220:
This song is so great.  Cracks me up everytime I hear it.  There are very few bands that could get away with these lyrics.  I don't see how anyone could be exclusively an OGT.  I enjoy Opiate as much as the next guy, but it is far from their best stuff.  I would rate Jerk Off as one of their best though.  That scream at the end (live mind you) is insanely wicked to the wicked degree.  

If they truly sold out, they would pump out a new album every year or two instead of every 4 or 5 years.  You know Adam could easily have his own silverburst line of guitars.  Heck, everyone one of those guys could have their name on something with the snap of their fingers.  Additionally, their music would gradually suck more and more, which has not happened.  In a day with so few decent bands, it's hard to call Tool sellouts.  If Tool is a sellout then EVERYONE is a sellout.  Sooooo, suck my balls!

comment_230:
The song is written to an individual who had interviewed Keenan.  Basically, what he's saying is You're wearing all this name brand shit and drinking name brand soda during this interview and you're calling ME a sellout??

And when he says "advice" with stress on the AD, he's speaking of advertising and marketing.
comment_231:
Biggest clue is in the beginning of the song: "claimed that he / was OGT / from '92 / the first EP ... "

OGT is "Original Gangster Tool," or someone who is not just a Tool fan, but who only listens to the "Opiate" EP (released in 1992, duh). Artists whose so-called hardcore fans accuse them of selling out may relate to this scenario, but the song specifically and intentionally confronts fans of early Tool -- people who refuse to accept the value and relevance of the band's more recent work.
comment_232: It refers to a fan who accused the band of going soft, or selling out after releasing 1992's Opiate. Maynard responds to the fan by pointing out the hypocrisy of such a statement, noting anyone who listens to bands and buys music is a sellout themselves and that everything you "read and wear and hear and see on TV is a product". "OGT" is taken to stand for "Original Gangster Tool"
